quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The company was on the verge of going under when we launched Bolt, and what ended up happening is, in the first two months it went from zero to 20 million of ARR.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A concrete example of extreme turnaround and rapid traction that underscores how quickly product-market fit can materialize after near-failure.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Most importantly, it's been the people. It's rare to find startups where you have the core group of five, six, seven people that have been there for five years plus.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Highlights team continuity as a key growth lever, suggesting long-tenured cores can compound execution speed and trust.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You basically were building a tech first, and then looking for a problem to solve later, which is often what people tell you not to do.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Surfaces a counterintuitive product approach—deep tech first, problem second—that challenges standard startup advice.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: There are periods of time where you have to make judgment calls that are not going to be the consensus view. You got to have confidence in your convictions on how to best play the hand.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A decision-making mindset for founders: expect non-consensus calls and rely on conviction when data and agreement are limited.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It was kind of like, Bolt's this overnight success, seven years in the making.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that emphasizes hidden compounding work behind “sudden” breakout growth.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth, and for understanding the performance of new features, and Eppo helps you increase experimentation velocity while unlocking rigorous deep analysis, in a way that no other commercial tool does.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Highlights experimentation as a core growth discipline and emphasizes pairing speed (velocity) with rigor (deep analysis).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo does all that and more, with advanced statistical methods that can help you shave weeks off experiment time, and accessible UI for diving deeper into performance, and out-of-the-box reporting that helps you avoid annoying, prolonged analytics cycles.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on what to look for in experimentation tooling: faster time-to-results, self-serve analysis, and reduced reporting overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo also makes it easy for you to share experiment insights with your team, sparking new ideas for the A-B testing flywheel.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Introduces a practical growth loop: sharing learnings to generate more test ideas and compound experimentation output.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The fund holds $1.1 billion worth of institutional caliber real estate, managed by team of pros focused on steadily growing your net worth for decades to come.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Provides a concrete data point and a long-term compounding model for real estate investing.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Full disclosure, real estate investing is boring.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Counterintuitive framing that “boring” can be a feature for long-term wealth-building strategies.

quotes.topic_title: What Bolt is and what it enables
quotes.text: It's really simple. You go there, there's a text box, and you tell it what you want to build.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Highlights a low-friction, prompt-first workflow as the core product model practitioners can emulate to reduce time-to-value.

quotes.topic_title: What Bolt is and what it enables
quotes.text: And it's not just building a static site, or something like that, but you can actually build full stack, real software with databases, and hosting and et cetera, just from prompting.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Clarifies the scope shift from “static site generators” to full-stack app generation, useful for positioning and product expectations.

quotes.topic_title: What Bolt is and what it enables
quotes.text: And in a ridiculously short period of time, it's not like you're spending hours and hours or days, putting this together. You can get results in like, a minute.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Provides a concrete speed benchmark (“like, a minute”) that teams can use as a target for iteration loops and onboarding wow-moments.

quotes.topic_title: Hypergrowth metrics and why it’s real
quotes.text: And what ended up happening is, in the first two months, we went from zero to 20 million of ARR.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A concrete hypergrowth benchmark that anchors the rest of the discussion in measurable outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Hypergrowth metrics and why it’s real
quotes.text: We've added three million registered users just in the past few months here, and monthly active users is around a million, I think at this point, per month.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Shows the revenue surge is paired with massive user adoption, not just pricing or one-off deals.

quotes.topic_title: Hypergrowth metrics and why it’s real
quotes.text: So from my view, I was also very skeptical, as this. I've never seen anything grow like this, right? And so part of me, for like a month I was kind of waking up waiting for the day where it just was like, "Okay, it's over."
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Captures the counterintuitive reality that even insiders doubt AI-driven growth until retention data proves it.

quotes.topic_title: Hypergrowth metrics and why it’s real
quotes.text: And the value proposition is real. The free market is filled with rational actors. People are coming to these tools because it is solving problems, they're able to do way more for way less cost, than it would otherwise.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A mental model for validating AI product growth: sustained adoption signals real economic value, not hype.

quotes.topic_title: Hypergrowth metrics and why it’s real
quotes.text: In a sense, it's almost like maybe the new normal, as AI just continues to get better.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A provocative claim that challenges conventional startup growth expectations in the AI era.

quotes.topic_title: Bolt demo: speed, reliability, and WebContainers
quotes.text: And I think that the biggest difference between Bolt and the other stuff out there, it's actually subtle. It's not like something you'd necessarily see in the UI, but it's how fast it is, and how reliable it is.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Highlights a product differentiation lens: the most important advantages may be non-obvious in the UI and instead show up as speed/reliability in real use.

quotes.topic_title: Bolt demo: speed, reliability, and WebContainers
quotes.text: Everyone else runs those things on cloud servers, which those can take minutes to boot up, and they often will run into issues, and then you can end up literally stuck and have to contact support to get it done, and get it unstuck.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A concrete critique of the common cloud-dev-environment approach, pointing to boot-time and reliability as practical failure modes.

quotes.topic_title: Bolt demo: speed, reliability, and WebContainers
quotes.text: With Bolt, and for the past seven years, what our company's been doing has been building an operating system that runs inside of your browser locally, using your CPU. So we have a very permissive free tier, and it's insanely fast, and it's insanely reliable.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Explains the underlying methodology (local-in-browser compute) and ties architecture directly to business model (permissive free tier) and UX outcomes (speed/reliability).

quotes.topic_title: Bolt demo: speed, reliability, and WebContainers
quotes.text: There would not be a Bolt without this technology called WebContainer, that allows us to run an operating system in the browser.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A clear statement of the core enabling technology and why it’s foundational to the product’s experience.

quotes.topic_title: Bolt demo: speed, reliability, and WebContainers
quotes.text: And again, this is doing this entirely inside of my browser, so it doesn't cost us anything to do this. So again, you can do this for free, and it has gone ahead and deployed this on a real URL, on Netlify.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Actionable example of how local compute can reduce marginal costs and enable free, real deployment workflows via integrations.

quotes.topic_title: Deploying apps and replacing Wix-like workflows
quotes.text: So with Bolt, we actually have built-in integrations with production grade hosting providers like Netlify, and for databases with Supabase.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Highlights a practical methodology: ship real apps by bundling deployment + database integrations directly into the builder.

quotes.topic_title: Deploying apps and replacing Wix-like workflows
quotes.text: So if I go and just click the deploy button here, this is actually going to run a production build of this project we made here.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Actionable product insight: one-click deploy should trigger a true production build, not a demo or preview environment.

quotes.topic_title: Deploying apps and replacing Wix-like workflows
quotes.text: This is live, I can share this with anyone, and if I want to buy the domain spotifyclone.com, and point it at this, I can click this link here.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Concrete example of reducing friction from prototype to public launch by making URL sharing and custom domains part of the workflow.

quotes.topic_title: Deploying apps and replacing Wix-like workflows
quotes.text: And then it hit me. Those things are so complicated to use.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Counterintuitive observation: mainstream website builders can be too complex for many users, creating an opening for simpler app-building tools.

quotes.topic_title: Deploying apps and replacing Wix-like workflows
quotes.text: There's no way you could actually build a functional app.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Memorable differentiation claim that reframes “website builders” as fundamentally limited compared to tools designed for real app functionality.

quotes.topic_title: Mobile apps with Expo partnership demo
quotes.text: This is kind of the first time that, you don't have to be technical to make production grade web, full-stack web and mobile apps. At this point I've done nothing that requires developer knowledge to do any of this stuff.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Highlights a step-change in who can build real software, reframing prototyping and iteration as accessible to non-developers via prompting.

quotes.topic_title: Mobile apps with Expo partnership demo
quotes.text: the majority of our audience are people that are not developers, that are using this. They're PMs, they're designers, they're entrepreneurs.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A concrete adoption signal that the primary users are practitioners closest to product discovery, not engineers.

quotes.topic_title: Mobile apps with Expo partnership demo
quotes.text: Because these are people that have always been great at building products, but previously, the only way that they could get their ideas into coded software was through a developer's fingertips. And now, they can deal with their own, through prompting.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of the bottleneck shift—from engineering gatekeeping to direct iteration by product builders.

quotes.topic_title: Mobile apps with Expo partnership demo
quotes.text: it's like if you and I were building an app together, we could be on other sides of the planet and you could actually be not just seeing a screenshot of the thing, but actually touching it and feeling it, and putting it through its paces.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Defines a new collaboration workflow: remote teams can validate product experience hands-on instead of relying on static mocks.

quotes.topic_title: Mobile apps with Expo partnership demo
quotes.text: it's faster to do this than design a whole bunch of Figma frames, necessarily.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Counterintuitive product-development claim that interactive app prototypes can outpace traditional design-first mock workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Seven-year tech bet: origin of WebContainer
quotes.text: StackBlitz was a browser-based, deep technology play on, "Can we make a web assembly based operating system that can boot in a browser, in like a hundred milliseconds, and run full on development tool chains?"
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A clear articulation of an ambitious technical “bet” framed as a concrete performance + capability target.

quotes.topic_title: Seven-year tech bet: origin of WebContainer
quotes.text: That's the only model that's ever scaled to a billion users.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A scaling mental model: pushing compute to the client (like Docs/Figma) is the proven path to massive scale.

quotes.topic_title: Seven-year tech bet: origin of WebContainer
quotes.text: And the problem is, on a small scale it can work, but as you scale it up, I mean there's not even a 100 million VMs to rent, on the planet. But there are a billion devices that you can run this stuff on.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A concrete constraint-based argument (VM scarcity vs device abundance) for why browser-native compute can outscale cloud-VM architectures.

quotes.topic_title: Seven-year tech bet: origin of WebContainer
quotes.text: What we struggled with for the years after that was just how to build a product around it, because developers loved it, but they weren't using it in ways that they would pay money for.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A practical product lesson: technical admiration doesn’t equal willingness-to-pay, so packaging and monetizable use-cases matter.

quotes.topic_title: Seven-year tech bet: origin of WebContainer
quotes.text: One is, you basically were building a tech first, and then looking for a problem to solve later. Which is often what people tell you not to do. And it worked out, in this case.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive methodology: tech-first exploration can work when the underlying platform shift is big enough.

quotes.topic_title: Startup survival: low burn, contrarian decisions
quotes.text: And then I think the other lesson here is just, as a founder, just survive as long as you can. Because you may find something that works.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A simple survival-first mental model: maximize time alive to increase chances of finding product-market fit.

quotes.topic_title: Startup survival: low burn, contrarian decisions
quotes.text: So we understood out of it how to have a low burn rate, and take a lot of shots on goal, and make every dollar stretch beyond what anyone would think is reasonable or possible.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A concrete operating methodology: low burn + many experiments + extreme frugality to extend runway and learning cycles.

quotes.topic_title: Startup survival: low burn, contrarian decisions
quotes.text: And I would just say generally, until you see pull, just people pulling the product out of your hands, you don't want to be spending money. You should be like, default, no.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A decision rule for spending: delay costs until unmistakable demand appears, and default to saying no.

quotes.topic_title: Startup survival: low burn, contrarian decisions
quotes.text: During a time in which, during 2020, through 2020 and 2021, which were times where exuberance and growing headcount was like, KPIs of companies.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A specific example of a market-wide trap: treating headcount growth as a success metric during boom years.

quotes.topic_title: Startup survival: low burn, contrarian decisions
quotes.text: And I'm glad that we didn't heed the advice, because if we had tripled the company and kicked up the burn rate, there would be no Bolt. We would've gone out of business a lot of time ago.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A contrarian call with clear stakes: resisting hiring pressure preserved runway and kept the company alive.

quotes.topic_title: Launch story: a tweet, then chaos scaling
quotes.text: And I think on the first day, I think we added 60K of ARR, or something. Which was like, I mean, crazy. Again, we were at 600, so we added 10% in a day.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark for recognizing real launch traction fast (and calibrating what “working” can look like).

quotes.topic_title: Launch story: a tweet, then chaos scaling
quotes.text: We built Bolt in 90. So there's a lot of things that were missing in the product. Like, basic stuff, basic stuff.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Highlights a speed-to-market methodology: ship in ~90 days and accept missing “basics” to capture demand early.

quotes.topic_title: Launch story: a tweet, then chaos scaling
quotes.text: we got to 20 million of ARR without a mobile responsive view, by the way. Just throwing that out there.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that “must-have” UX polish can be deferred if core value is strong enough.

quotes.topic_title: Launch story: a tweet, then chaos scaling
quotes.text: And what we ended up stumbling into is that, "Okay, actually, people are willing to pay more. People want to pay for more inference, because we've crossed this threshold where you can get a very tangible ROI."
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A pricing mental model: once users see tangible ROI, usage-based expansion can beat flat “Netflix model” pricing.

quotes.topic_title: Launch story: a tweet, then chaos scaling
quotes.text: Anthropic ran out of GPUs for us. Dario emailed me, he was like, "Listen, we don't have anything more to give you."
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A vivid scaling constraint example: external infrastructure limits can become the bottleneck even when demand is exploding.

quotes.topic_title: How a 15–20 person team pulled it off
quotes.text: It's rare to find startups where you have the core group of five, six, seven people, that have been there for five years, plus.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Highlights long-tenured teams as a key (and uncommon) ingredient for executing ambitious, multi-year bets.

quotes.topic_title: How a 15–20 person team pulled it off
quotes.text: And the problem with the turnover like that is that you can't take really long bets like the one we did.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Connects low turnover directly to the ability to pursue long-horizon strategies that wouldn’t survive constant team churn.

quotes.topic_title: How a 15–20 person team pulled it off
quotes.text: Just having less people, and more context per head.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A memorable operating principle for small teams: maximize shared context rather than headcount.

quotes.topic_title: How a 15–20 person team pulled it off
quotes.text: The second thing, everyone has agency to actually get stuff done, front to back.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Advocates for end-to-end ownership as a practical way to move fast without coordination overhead.

quotes.topic_title: How a 15–20 person team pulled it off
quotes.text: So when you look at what happened with Bolt, I mean, we had engineers that were, front to back, were on a call with someone running into an issue, going and fixing it. Cooking up the UI on the spot, and landing this thing. Without involving anyone else on the team.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Concrete example of high-agency execution: engineers handle customer support, product/UI changes, and shipping in one loop.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring philosophy and remote-first team building
quotes.text: Yeah, for us, and even if the folks were hiring us, hiring people that don't care about the titles, and they don't care about... It's not like they're... People, of course it's people have a career trajectory, and that sort of thing, but they really are motivated by just working on cool things, and are chucking their ego at the door.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A clear hiring filter: prioritize low-ego, intrinsically motivated builders over title-driven candidates.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring philosophy and remote-first team building
quotes.text: And they're there to collectively build something great, not just kind of follow, and be the brilliant jerk.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Memorable team norm that rejects the “brilliant jerk” archetype in favor of collaborative execution.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring philosophy and remote-first team building
quotes.text: It's funny, back in 2018, we rented an office and stuff, and we were commuting into it. Because we thought we'd hire people here, and like a year into it we were like, "What are we doing? You and I are coming to an office for 10 people, we've hired, the people working for us are in Europe, or across the US."
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A concrete example of realizing remote-first hiring makes a physical office unnecessary (and even irrational).

quotes.topic_title: Hiring philosophy and remote-first team building
quotes.text: And then the first people that we hired, the reason that we found them is that they were users of StackBlitz. A lot of people, the majority of people we've hired at the company have been people that actually came from our community, basically.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: Actionable recruiting strategy: hire from your product’s user community, where motivation and product familiarity are pre-vetted.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring philosophy and remote-first team building
quotes.text: So when we want to hire people, we put out a tweet and say, "Hey, we're hiring an engineer," and then we get DMs or whatever.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A lightweight, repeatable hiring channel that leverages community reach instead of traditional recruiting pipelines.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Yes, so we just launched OneSchema FileFeeds, which allows you to build an integration with any system in 15 minutes, as long as you can export a CSV to an SFTP folder.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: A concrete, time-bound methodology for rapidly shipping integrations by standardizing on CSV-to-SFTP as the interface.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We allow our customers to offer thousands of integrations without involving their engineering team at all.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: A scalable operating model: decouple integration breadth from engineering bandwidth to unlock growth.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We've heard so many horror stories of multi-day outages, from even just a handful of bad records.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: A vivid reliability lesson that small data quality issues can cascade into major operational incidents.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We have a built-in validation layer that stops any bad data from entering your system, and OneSchema will notify your team immediately of any data that looks incorrect.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: Actionable integration practice: prevent failures by validating at the boundary and alerting quickly on anomalies.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritization, daily all-hands, and lightweight PRDs
quotes.text: Best example was last week with native mobile app support. That's, by reception, the biggest thing we've ever launched. And it was something that, even internally at the company, some folks were like, "This, I don't know. People are yelling about these other things." And it is, it's always this balance of how much are we just triaging various things, versus that new capabilities, but it was like, "This strikes me as an important one," where we put some chips into the middle of the table on. And had it dead right.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A concrete example of making a conviction bet despite louder user requests—and it becoming their biggest launch.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritization, daily all-hands, and lightweight PRDs
quotes.text: It's just this mind-blowing experience, and now, there's just thousands of mobile apps being created a day, that weren't before.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A specific outcome/data point illustrating how a single prioritization decision can unlock massive new user behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritization, daily all-hands, and lightweight PRDs
quotes.text: I think the best analogy would be like, it's kind of like working at a restaurant, being like a chef. There's some amount of, there's feedback from the customers of, "This thing didn't taste good." And then there's like, "Hey, we've been cooking something interesting, and this tastes... I don't know. This, I think you're going to like this. I think this is a killer dish." And so you kind of have to balance those things.
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for balancing reactive customer feedback with proactive product bets.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritization, daily all-hands, and lightweight PRDs
quotes.text: Yeah, every day at 8:00 AM Pacific, we're on a Zoom for at least an hour-
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: An operational practice (daily full-company sync) that teams can copy during hypergrowth to stay aligned.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritization, daily all-hands, and lightweight PRDs
quotes.text: But the thing about just having everyone in the same room every day is that, a lot of people will complain that it's... On Twitter, you'll see people say, "Oh, it's the most expensive use of everyone's time," but it's like, "Yep. But there's 0% fidelity loss in that. Everything, every day, is being audited front to back, and being discussed front to back."
quotes.speaker: Eric Simons
quotes.context: A contrarian argument that the cost of all-hands can be worth it to minimize communication loss during extreme growth.
